awd_titl_txt: CC* Network Design: The Western South Dakota Research and Education Network
awd_abstract_narration:
High-speed connectivity to remote state and national cyberinfrastructure resources such as advanced computing systems, data stores, and scientific instrumentation is crucial in states like South Dakota. For this project, the South Dakota School of Mines and Technology (SDSM&T) and Black Hills State University (BHSU) are collaborating with the University of South Dakota (USD) to transform the way campus and state networks are designed and operated by addressing the unique challenges of deploying accessible cyberinfrastructure in a rural state. Specifically, SDSM&T and BHSU are building out campus network infrastructure in support of multidisciplinary research and education including: advanced imaging and microscopy, underground science, weather prediction, and high throughput genetic sequencing.

With a system architecture conceived and designed in year 1 and deployed in year 2 this project aims to increase STEM research and education productivity in western South Dakota by re-architecting campus networks and regional aggregation points so that they are optimized for current and future research and education applications. Architectural characteristics include aspects of the Science DMZ approach to streamline academic data flows; improved wired and wireless connections within and between science buildings and the network core; network measurement leveraging existing campus edge PerfSONAR nodes as well as new nodes at each campus core; data transfer nodes based on the Flash IO Network Appliance; and Globus middleware for data movement. With guidance from state, regional, and national advisors this collaboration is establishing an aggregation model for accessible cyberinfrastructure in rural regions where under-resourced institutions are the norm.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Expanding opportunities for data-driven and computation-intensive research have resulted in a growing need for increased network capabilities for both intra- and inter-campus data movement. This is especially challenging for under-resourced institutions in rural states where awareness and literacy of advanced digital resources are still emerging.

The Western South Dakota Research and Education Network addresses these challenges at the South Dakota School of Mines & Technology (SDSMT) and Black Hills State University (BHSU). This project re-architects campus networks and regional aggregation points so that they are optimized for current and future research and education applications. Architectural characteristics include aspects of the ESnet Science DMZ model to streamline research and academic data flows; improved wired and wireless connections within and between science buildings and the network core; network measurement leveraging existing campus edge perfSONAR nodes as well as new nodes at each campus core; data transfer nodes based on the Flash IO Network Appliance; and Globus middleware for data movement. With guidance from state, regional, and national advisors, this collaboration establishes an aggregation model for accessible cyberinfrastructure in rural regions where under-resourced institutions are the norm.

The Western South Dakota Research and Education Network directly supports numerous STEM projects across seven departments among the two institutions, and expands research and education collaboration opportunities throughout South Dakota and beyond. Examples of supported research efforts include:

  • Developing computational training and distance learning aimed at providing non-Computer Science researchers the tools and training required to make effective use of HPC hardware and tools.
  • Supporting molecular genetics research in South Dakota by providing research infrastructure, services, and education in the area of genetics and genomics to faculty and student researchers, including Sanger sequencing of nucleic acids, genotyping, qPCR and NextGen nucleic acid sequencing.
  • Realtime regional numerical weather prediction and climate study, requiring intensive computational power and large storage volumes to create timely guidance for students, researchers, policy makers, and stakeholders.
  • Nanomaterials characterization for biological systems, including nanoparticle drug delivery both in vitro and in vivo, providing a foundation that can be easily tailored depending on the characteristics of the disease.

As a capstone to the project, South Dakota hosted the NSF-funded Engagement and Performance Operations Center (EPOC) for a virtual Application Deep Dive. Originally planned only for SDSMT and BHSU, this engagement was expanded to study scientific workflows and associated technological challenges across all six of South Dakota’s public universities.

Through this project, the South Dakota School of Mines & Technology and Black Hills State University have successfully transformed their campus networks into modern environments for accelerated data movement impacting research and STEM education, and the multi-institutional nature of the project has strengthened research-focused collaboration among researchers and IT staff throughout South Dakota’s public higher education system.
